subject: The ROGUES Are Coming
event:
Gardner Dozois and I have just delivered the completed manuscript (well, e-manuscript, it being 2013 and all) for our latest big cross-genre anthologies, ROGUES, to our editor at Bantam Spectra.

Once again, we've got a really kickass lineup of contributors, and some terrific stories.

The table of contents:

George R.R. Martin            “Everybody Loves a Rogue”  (Introduction)
Joe Abercrombie               “Tough Times All Over”
Gillian Flynn                 “What Do You Do?”
Matthew Hughes                “The Inn of the Seven Blessings”
Joe R. Lansdale               “Bent Twig”
Michael Swanwick              “Tawny Petticoats”
David  Ball                   “Provenance”
Carrie Vaughn                 “The Roaring Twenties”
Scott Lynch                   “A Year and a Day in Old Theradane”
Bradley Denton                “Bad Brass”
Cherie Priest                 “Heavy Metal”
Daniel Abraham                “The Meaning of Love”
Paul Cornell                  “A Better Way to Die”
Steven Saylor                 “Ill Seen in Tyre”
Garth Nix                     “A Cargo of Ivories”
Walter Jon Williams           “Diamonds From Tequila”   
Phyllis Eisenstein            “The Caravan to Nowhere”
Lisa Tuttle                   “The Curious Affair of the Dead Wives”
Neil Gaiman                   “How the Marquis Got His Coat Back”  
Connie Willis                 “Now Showing”
Patrick Rothfuss              “The Lightning Tree” 

This one was an enormous amount of fun.  We're got something for everyone in ROGUES -- SF, mystery, historical fiction, epic fantasy, sword and sorcery, comedy, tragedy, crime stories, mainstream.  And rogues, cads, scalawags, con men, thieves, and scoundrels of all descriptions.  If you love Harry Flashman and Cugel the Clever, as I do, this is the book for you.

If there's any bloody justice, some of these stories will contend for awards.  

(And it's one more monkey off my back, hurrah, hurrah)

comments.article: I'm really looking forward to this one.
That is a bad-ass lineup. :D 2014 is going to rule...thanks for giving me one more thing to look forward to!
Are there others like this already published involving you? If so I may have to get my wallet out!

Yes, Gardner and I have done a number of anthologies together.

Already published are WARRIORS, SONGS OF LOVE AND DEATH, DOWN THESE STRANGE STREETS, and SONGS OF THE DYING EARTH. The last is a tribute anthology to Jack Vance.

Delivered and forthcoming are DANGEROUS WOMEN from Tor and OLD MARS from Bantam. And now ROGUES.

We are still at work on OLD VENUS.

The rumors of an OLD URANUS are unfounded.

One less monkey!
Keep up the awesome work, George! :)

comments.article: Can these books be ordered signed? After getting my signed anthologies I don't fancy buying a "naked" copy :)
Feeling a bit aprehensive about this to be honest. I bought the "Songs of Love and Death" anthologie and by the end of it I honestly felt cheated.

Sorry to hear that... but, thankfully, you were in a small minority on that one. The reviews for LOVE AND DEATH were very good, and two of the stories therein were nominated for Edgar Awards.

But not all books are for all readers.

I first started reading A Song of Ice and Fire around when Clash of Kings came out. I've loved it ever since.

I recently read Tuf Voyaging, which I really enjoyed. It has me excited to read your other works. I'm looking forward to reading Wild Cards in the near future.

I was curious what other sci-fi and fantasy fiction you would strongly recommend or advocate to your readers? Is it fair to assume that the writers featured in anthologies in which you've been involved come especially recommended? I am particularly interested in works that feature deep, complicated characters.

Thank you for everything.

_ Michael Hoffman

- Michael
